text:
This will make only sense if you were at Beaumont Leys School 40 years ago:

"What's the best Brexit deal, Mr  Groom?"

"Norway, lad. Norway."

Does anyone else remember?
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text: Not bad at all - but you've disenfranchised those genteel Norway backers. And PV HQ don't like "no deal" appearing on any ballot paper in case it wins. Another go?

text:
I'm truly sorry Carl, but Murphy's Other Law states that anyone who cites Hitler in a political discussion automatically loses the argument ;-)
Harsh but necessary

text:

Letwin&Co have devised this brilliant different idea, using deferred divisions to carry out simultaneous voting.

text:
May now facing multiple calls to resign from Tory Right-wingers.

Too many mis-steps this week. Her rudder is gone

This feels like the tipping point - after which a capsize is inevitable.

Her days as Prime Minister  are numbered.
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text:

text:
The Art Of The Deal (UK Govt version).

"You can have an extension until May 22 or until the end of the year, but not during the elections in June."

"I want June 30. Give me June 30.  Me want June 30!"

"It's May 22"

"er, OK"

#festivalofbrexitbritain
author: JoeMurphyLondon
JoeMurphyLondon

text:
Dawn of the TIGs 

Con 38  (nc)
Lab  34 (-4)
LD 8(-2)
Ukip 7 (+3)
TIG 2 
Brexit 1

OK, the TIGs and Brexit aren't parties yet, but @IpsosMORI did not prompt for them (ie, voters came up with them unprompted) so its only fair to show the impact they're having.

@EveningStandard
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text:
But supporters of poor Jeremy Corbyn have nothing to cheers about:

His ratings are also dire
Just as few think he could get a good Brexit deal.
And Labour has slipped behind  the Tories in the voting intentions 

@ipsosMORI @EveningStandard
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text:
May's Government has the worst satisfaction rating since the darkest days of civil war under John Major - which ended in 13 years of opposition.

@IpsosMORI
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text: Just 18% think May can get a  good Brexit deal.  Who would have believed she could fall lower than the 21% recorded in  January.

text: POLL:  Theresa May's worst ratings as PM and her lowest for Brexit handling.  Public's verdict revealed by @IpsosMORI in tonight's @eveningstandard

“Today represents a further event in a catastrophic failure of the political process — here and in the EU. That we are where we are with a week or so to go before Mar 29 is nothing short of ....

text: 64 labour MPs abstained and 13 voted against in the whipped vote to sack Mike Gapes and Ian Austin from committee posts. That’s a massive rebellion.
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text: Rebellious Labour MPs are planning to abstain in vote to sack select committee members Mike Gapes of @TheIndGroup & Ian Austin, a plain Independent.
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text: Yup, going "batshit" at ministers for leaking Cabinet really did the trick.
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text:
With her Cabinet imploding, Theresa May finally asks for a Brexit delay and admits UK is facing 'crisis' 
So, no surprises then.
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text: Theresa May has invited @BorisJohnson into No 10  for a chinwag (presumably asking what is his price to back her deal).  She must be desperate as BoJo has been very clear he would need the backstop removed. He slipped in via Cabinet office
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text: France's Europe minister Nathalie Loiseau has called her cat Brexit -- cos it never knows whether it wants to go in or out
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text: Ouch - it appears that the only country not ready for a no-deal Brexit is .... this one.

text: @GuyVerhofstadt asks "Why should the EU27 even consider a Brexit extension this week, if the UK parliament vote on the deal is cancelled?”

text: The concession that let May win by just two votes ... to let Parliament take control from Monday March 25
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text: ... and her own Chief Whip abstained in the free vote shortly after bollocking Cabinet members who abstained (on a whipped vote) yesterday
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text:
More news from the Mad World of May's Brexit....

The Brexit Secretary voted against the very Government motion that he actually spoke for at the Dispatch Box.
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text:
More than half the House voted against 2nd referendum in an 85 to 334 rout.  Even with Labour support it was dead.

Makes you wonder why Theresa May is so dead set against indicative votes
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text: Not a great look for Labour. They stay in their seats while other parties are voting on a ⁦@peoplesvote_uk⁩ referendum.

text: Welcome to the mad world of May's Brexit Britain

A job for Jack Whitehouse perhaps?

text: On this occasion, the Speaker is surely right.  Why should one MP be able to withdraw an amendment that many MPs have signed and hope to vote on?

text:
Wow, has the Speaker ever before told an MP they can;t withdraw a motion because "other signatories" 
can move it?

A big precedent if not - and one that will make future votes more interesting and less easy for the whips to nobble
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text:

Maybe they are just telling the truth about seeing a precipitous drop in confidence and demand - &, worryingly, that wealthy professionals are leaving London
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text:
You may be right - but a senior minister who served several years as a PPS says they are actually backbenchers, although subject to collective responsibility and members of the Govt. 
he says the key is that a PPS can take part in backbench debates while frontbenchers can’t.
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text: Top splash by @KateProctor on the story that was obviously going to run and run until Chris Williamson was suspended - obvious to all except those who didn't suspend him until 5 minutes ago
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text:
Here's why it is terrible politics:

Mrs May herself traipsed around the EU in 2016 asking for a separate deal on citizen rights. She was shown the door by Merkel & Co who refused to negotiate until A50 was triggered.

But now she gives the impression of opposing those rights
...
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text:
Costa's proposal does not breach collective responsibility (although everyone will assume that the PM is opposed to it now)

He was handed the silver revolver because PPSs (junior minister aides) aren't supposed to put down amendments to Government Bills. 

...
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text:
Nice backbencher @AlbertoCostaMP has been given the boot for putting down an amendment calling on the PM to seek a separate treaty on EU citizens' rights as an insurance against no-deal.

It's widely backed by all sides, from Jacob Rees Mogg to Caroline Lucas

....
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text:
Only in the mad world of May's Brexit ....

In a week that Cabinet unity collapsed before our eyes without any minister being sacked ...

... a lowly PPS has been made to resign on a technicality
 
thread
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text:
More trouble:  Ministers believe the EU will insist on up to two year delay if the Brexit deal is voted down.
Exclusive by @nicholascecil and me
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text: To be fair, you had an awful lot
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text: You mean this scoop, Phil?
author: JoeMurphyLondon

text:
I'm told the big Brexiteers in Cabinet sounded "sheepish" when asked beforehand by supporters if they would push back against the forces of Rudd & Co.

No resignations today.
author: JoeMurphyLondon
